response.answer_text: Lots and lots of answers here, all respectable, and yet, it would seem, all from, shall we say, outsiders. I’d like to share a perspective “from the inside”. It’s a small data set, but it’s accurate for what it represents. (And of course it is not an exhaustive explanation.) The answer from this “insider” is yes, and yes, with some important caveats. Many of the answers below describe narcissism pretty well, but incompletely. I will try to share some salient points that may have been missing in others’ answers. Again, from an insider’s perspective. A narcissist doesn’t really know he’s a narcissist. And he has no idea he’s insecure. And he has no idea why people don’t understand that he’s right. This perplexing problem arises from very low-level code running in the consciousness of a narcissist. And that program is: “The world is as I say it is. Anything in my experience that conflicts with my perceptions of how things are/should be is an error in reality that must be understood, accounted for, and mitigated or corrected through my clever machinations.” The behavior that results - or rather, the motivation for that behavior - is not selfishness as we commonly understand it. It is not manipulation by a con man. That kind of behavior is code running way above the narcissism layer. Those people are not mentally ill. They’re just dicks. What it is, instead, is an ardent striving to make the world behave as it should. This lens is the reason we see narcissists treating everything, including people, as objects to be manipulated. It’s all about making lived experience match the internal projection (not the other way around, as most of us have learned). Read that again. What you perceive as selfishness and manipulation is actually an attempt to “fix” a world that is not operating as it should. What are some of those machinations? PersuasionFlatteryCompelling story-telling (which you might at times experience as gaslighting)Shapeshifting (which you might at times experience as lack of authenticity).Let’s focus on the last one, because it’s illuminating to the inner world of the narcissist. The narcissist has no idea that he’s insecure. He’s so insecure, at such a deep level, that his ego is actually covering up every indication of insecurity by projecting dysfunction onto the external world. From his frame of reference, he’s not insecure. - he’s right - 99.99% of the time - and you just can’t see it yet. So his job is to make you see it, so that yet another error in reality can be corrected. To that end, he will shape-shift - he will be whoever, whatever, he needs to be to get you to see what he sees. For example, to get you to see how good a person he is, so that You will not be disappointed, so that you will not be hurt. So that you will be able to enjoy a perfected reality, and,You will like him, and perform for him, and inject the pleasure into his life that he perceives should be there, if the world were operating correctly.This is not an act of cruelty. It’s an act of service, and to some extent, an effort at enlightenment. Until you fail to become enlightened. And eventually the process of shapeshifting becomes exhausting, and he has to, out of self-preservation, abandon his attempt to enlighten you. And then you become intolerable - an intimate, and therefore intolerable, error in reality - and he needs to escape from you. But it’s not because he doesn’t care about you. He does. Often deeply. But you’re broken, and therefor toxic, and so he can only hang out with you while you’re able to see clearly. And when you can’t, it’s too painful. The common perception is that the narcissist feels threatened. But that’s not his perception. His perception is that you’re just wrong, and maybe a bit pitiful for being unable to see and grow and understand the truth. And, sadly, irritating for that. Does this sound like a cult leader? Yes? Good. You’re catching on. It’s a mistake to presume that a narcissist has mal-intent. I think, honestly, that it’s the opposite. But because the a priori position of a narcissist is that his view is the correct one, the only way he can help you is to help you to see as he sees. Perhaps that’s enough preamble. So can a narcissist be happy and successful? My limited data-set says that there is a slim chance that a narcissist can discover and admit that he is a narcissist, and through deep internal work, can relinquish the notion that he’s always right, can see the error in the programming, and can begin to embrace the world as it is, without needing to bend it to his perception. And then, the narcissist can begin to learn to be truly successful and truly happy. As many have pointed out, a run-of-the-mill narcissist can find material success. Perhaps more easily than many others. The “reality distortion field” a narcissist emits often magnetically harnesses the efforts of others to create fantastic material changes in the world. One might experience this skill-set and describe it as “leadership”, or “vision”. In fact, many of our most “successful” members of society have deep narcissistic tendencies, and the more successful they are, the more likely they have, at varying levels of intensity, “bent reality” to their will, for good or ill, and to the benefit or detriment to those around them. Happiness… and the more ephemeral, spiritual, humane success? That’s the hard part. The neural programming of a narcissist is very deep, and can catch the energy of even the most conscious narcissist unawares, dropping him back into old patterns. It helps to have someone close able to call him out, and remind him of his tendencies (tough, because even a recovering narcissist can keep hiding his true self, making real inter-personal intimacy very rare). And then, if we’re lucky, over time, the possibility exists that all the amazing skills that a narcissist has developed over the years to “fix” reality can be turned. Towards service. Serving the needs of others, and the broader agenda of lovingkindness, from a place of humility - that’s the winning slot. A tough transition for a narcissist. But if he can get there, he can be both happy and successful. Fulfilled even. It’s a long shot. But sometimes it happens. Think of “How the Grinch Stole Christmas”. A happy ending. Think of Apple Computers. A blessing in many ways. Think of Donald Trump, and Mitch McConnell. Like I said. It’s a long shot. Meanwhile, be prepared for unrelenting assumptions that the external world is clearly wrong, and the narcissist is clearly right. If he can break that mind-set, there’s a chance. If he can’t … well … as someone else suggested, enjoy the parts of the ride that are fun, but don’t get attached. One last thought: Narcissism runs rampant in White-Male-Western-European/American-Patriarchy. It’s not a bug - it’s a feature. It’s “worked” phenomenally well for centuries. We have reshaped the world, bent it to our will. Made reality to be as we have envisioned it. Have we been successful?Are we happy?

Hi Chris, thanks for the ask. I guess it depends on how one defines success. My ex narc has a beautiful home, almost paid off and he's getting ready to install a pool, he has exotic cars and wads of cash in his pocket most of the time. He can do anything and go anywhere he wants, any time he wants. He built his business here in the valley from the ground up and was the pioneer in his field in the beginning, and now the one that his competitors try to imitate. He has women falling all over him all the time and wanting to be a permanent part of his life. He is well known, (at least his surface self) in the community and at the local Catholic church, to which he donated several hundred thousand dollars to help pay for he construction years ago. So I guess you could say he has success. Happiness? Absolutely not. He has 6 children, only two of them really talk to him. The youngest, because she is still a minor and lives with him half the time. And the second youngest because he works for his dad's company and they talk about work. The second oldest talks to him but doesn't come around much, doesn't confide in him and generally keeps him at an arms length. The oldest hasn’t talked to him in over 4 years. The other two come around on Thanksgiving or Christmas and call on his birthday that's about it. He doesn't have any friends and his family (8 living siblings plus the in-laws) have a very difficult time hiding their disdain for him. So they've just given up and are pretty out in the open about it. It's easier than trying to hide it. His neices and nephews can't stand him except for one or two he is close with. The only reason he makes the 10 hour trip back home is to see his parents. But once they are gone I doubt he'll go there much. He tried for a long time to marry me and I loved him but I knew he didn't really love me. It was very difficult because I genuinely did love him. So success, yes I guess. If success is all the material things. Happiness will be elusive to him until the day he dies.

Thanks for the A2A. My former NPD had an excellent job in the computer/IT technology field. It certainly is a lucrative paying job. He seems to have some problems finding or maintaining work in the field for awhile. He had some issues a few years back with a on-site office version of his job with other employees. They were apparently finding him threatening, loud and rude. Some truly feared him. I’d imagine that was likely true, considering his behavior around myself and my family. His boss and HR department sent him to work remotely from home for about a year, while the complaints and allegations were sorted out. He was eventually terminated of course. He seemed to really enjoy working remotely, as he didn’t have to really work much without any supervision, and made sure to only accomplish the bare minimum to keep future expectations low, and could abuse drugs freely all day. He only pursues remote jobs now, which all considered is probably a good fit. He doesn’t seem to be able to maintain employment for very long though, due to contracts not being refilled for him. I’m not sure if that’s just due to the nature of the field, a potentially unstable hostile personality or setting the bar just too low to appear accomplished in his work. When he does work, he makes excellent money though. As far as happiness, I’m not sure. How happy can someone really be when they have to blame a specific target for all their problems and issues in their life? When they continually cause conflicts for purposes of getting attention, making “interesting” topics of conversation for pity ploys. It seems like a dark existence to me to live like that, always avoiding any accountability by hurting those closest to you, in order to feel “popular” in a contrived world for everyone around you. Like some performer on a stage. Watching your partners leave you one by one… your children leave you… all those you hurt leave, wanting no contact ever again because of the scope of the abuses. Always having to create a character for yourself to make people like you. So many lies to have to keep straight in your head. I guess just make up a story for each potential obstacle and stick with it, but it has to get challenging to remember it all after awhile. And are they actually so delusional that they start to believe it and really live it, or do they just rationalize it as a necessary action caused by the other person‘s perceived slights each time? Hell, I get a little stressed just trying to wrap my head around it, can’t imagine actually living like that. It just doesn’t seem like that would really be a genuinely happy life… But they certainly seem to be able to find some joy through showing off nice possessions, acquisitions, financial accomplishments, and other nice things that they have that other people might envy, so maybe that really is enough for them? Maybe that feeling of superiority that they possess and crave really is all they need to feel fulfilled.

Well, like master kenobi said, that depends greatly your own point of view. If by happy and successful you mean, a complete 180 from where the narcissist is now, no more devaluing and discarding, no more smear campaigning and the rest, yes I think they can. Can, being the operative word here. They absolutely can. Anybody can. Will they, probably not. Firstly it would take tremendous amounts of work, and we all know the narcissist isn't going to make that effort. Secondly, they won't believe anyone who tells them there's something wrong with them in the first place. So it will never get to the putting in work stage. Now, if we're looking from the narcissists point of view, where they find someone who checks every one of their boxes, financially, emotionally, psychologically, and esthetically, whom obeys without question and hops too when prompted, and will never let the narcissist down, then the answer here is also yes. It, like all things is absolutely possible. Is it very probable, no. The narcissist, will always find something wrong and or get bored with their current SO, because thats all they received from their caregivers, during their devaluation. And yes, it was a devaluation, just like yours and mine. Their caregivers always found something wrong with the narcissists efforts. No matter how hard they tried, and how proud of themselves they may have been. And if they didn't find fault, they showed no interest, or what appeared to be boredom instead. To be perfectly honest, the narcissist never had a chance at a happy and normal life. They can achieve one, but the nature of their disorder won't allow it. Or very rarely anyway. I find that terribly terribly sad. They know exactly what they want, which is the same thing as all of us, but they themselves won't allow themselves to achieve it. Their disorder has them constantly chasing down Perfection, while simultaneously shooting down every candidate and their efforts. As a personal aside, I sincerely hope my narcissist either puts in the effort and finally, fully heals, or if not, finds the unicorn. That person I spoke of earlier that checks all of their boxes. Everyone, even our narcissists deserve a happy ending. I hope this answer helps. B

So his controlling personality honed organising skills, all helped along with manipulative tactics, gave him the ability to get what he wanted. The drive behind all this was a penchant for showing off. He had to have the best cars. The best everything actually, but particularly cars. There was a time when he arranged a mortgage against his house to buy a new Mercedes Benz. He couldn’t afford the model with the 500 V8 engine and had to be content with the smaller and cheaper 6 cylinder model. But not being one to miss an opportunity to show off, he went to the parts department and bought the badge for the 500V8 and stuck it on the back of the car to fool everyone! But I digress. The reality of this mans life was that he never did do anything. It was all done by his minions, those he controlled, manipulated and used. He was like an orchestra conductor, standing in the middle, waving his arms about as he directed all the things he wanted done. When anything was finally complete, he stood proud, accepting the accolades that then came to him. He probably looked happy while he posed with his car, or successful when he took a bow in front of the admiring crowd after some “achievement”, but those of us who were close knew different. There’s no real happiness behind that mask, and the only success he can really lay claim to is his ability to dupe others into carrying out his work and projects.

Usually, Narcs have more than one maladies… depends on what they struggle with… I will copy this note, but I don’t like these long winded responses: When we have a conscious over something, we experience emotion and sometimes pain. When people feel emotional pain, the same areas of the brain get activated as when people feel physical pain in the anterior insula and the anterior cingulate cortex. These regions are activated when people experienced a social rejection from peers. The same regions are activated when people who had recently broken up with romantic partners viewed pictures of the former partner. There is a power we have in relationships and it is not limited to domination and submission. That power is understood to be the respective abilities of each person in the connection to influence each other and direct the relationship. This is a very complex element in romantic partnerships when the elitist in the relationship takes control of those complex elements. Having power means to have a sense of control, to exercise choices and the ability to influence our environment and others. It's a natural and healthy instinct to exert our power to get our wants and needs met. Many relationships have power imbalances. If we’ve denied our power and don’t express ourselves for any of the above reasons, it’s natural for someone else to fill the vacuum. Often in codependent relationships, one partner may be an addict, narcissist, or abuser assumes to wield power over the other. Usually the submissive partner attempts to exert influence in indirect or passive-aggressive ways, such as withholding. Chronic lack of power can lead to depression, anxiety and other physical symptoms. Psychologically speaking, narcissism is a personality trait that every person possesses to some degree. Like any personal characteristic, it exists on a spectrum. Everyone falls somewhere along the narcissism continuum. Certain amounts of self-centeredness are healthy. It contributes to confidence, resilience, and ambition and certain agencies search out individuals with these traits. Nevertheless, any personality trait taken to an extreme can become pathological. A person who is excessively high in narcissism is said to have NPD (Narcissistic Personality Disorder), which is a diagnosable mental illness. The typical Narc is not oblivious to their condition, they have been conditioned, they are not Zombies. Love and friendship is something that most humans want and their intellect tells them to do these strange feats in that quest. They have developed unusual defense mechanisms similar to fight or flight. Some function quite well, some are monogamous, some are great providers because that’s what drives them… then some really need God’s help

Can a narcissist have a happy and “successful” life? What a good question and thank you for the A2A I believe a narcissist can have a “successful” life. If successful is a term used superficially, a person can appear to be very successful to others. So what is our definition of success? Lots of money? Lots of material things? Yes, I believe a narcissist can attain those. Is this life an empty one? I KNOW it would be for me. I have had “the material goods” at times in my life. But this is not the way of happiness. However, can a narcissist have a successful life in terms of relationships with others? My opinion is no or not likely. Let’s picture someone with a solid personal life…a home life. If our goal is to NURTURE love with a spouse and have normally developed children, then sadly, I believe a narcissist would fall short. Then let’s look at happiness…I read that in some opinion polls conducted, narcissists are happier than most people! How about that! They are able to pick up relationships and drop them off at will. Maybe that makes for “happy” people, I don’t know? When people get everything they want I believe they are usually unhappy. And the reason I believe that is because the thrill of the chase is what we go for. I’m referring to the chase as being setting a goal and going after that goal. If we suppose a guy meets a girl and all she wants out of life is to have a large house…she gets that from him but she doesn’t particularly have feelings for him. Is he going to be happy? So it depends on what you want. The point here is that a narcissist does not have the CHOICE of a life with more interesting, multi-faceted people. The narcissist’s choices are entirely different. They are based on different needs.

Careful about that “narcissist” diagnosis, since I doubt a professional diagnosis has been made there. You may be asking about some person who has some narcissistic TENDENCIES, and many of us do, so I’d say “yes”, a narcissist can have a happy and successful life. But, I also want you to think about your definition of “success” here. Is it financial success that you’re thinking of? I suspect it is, since that’s what many of us mean when we say “success”, and it’s FAR from the only, or the best, definition of success. A person with narcissistic tendencies CAN make changes to their personalities, whereas those who have a real personality disorder (the TRUE diagnosis) will be less able to make changes, and MUCH less inclined to do so. Real narcissists can be quite successful financially, as their particular disorder suits the accumulation of wealth and power most easily. And, they are less bothered by any considerations of what all this does to people along the way who they have stepped on or hurt or disadvantaged in their climb to wealth/power. Trump is a true narcissist of the most extreme kind. And we probably all know people who have those TENDENCIES, but are not as lethal or as profoundly self-centered as Trump. And, as for the “happiness” part of our question, I believe that the more closely one approaches a true and undiluted narcissism, the less possibility they would be truly happy people. Human happiness largely relies on human relationships, closeness, warmth of concern, mutual support and guidance, and the real narcissist will have little of that in his life - not much need for it and little desire for any of that complication. They may want APPLAUSE, but no closeness. They may want FOLLOWERS, but no real partners.
